author: Robert O'Brien
title: AMM for Continuous Financing
description: Financing innovation, science, and culture need complex economic protocols but developing these financial primitives is difficult.

assessments.note: If we as a cardano ecosystem want to dominate DeFi space than we will need Curve kind of protocol on cardano. As this proposal tackles the challenge to create an AMM protocol it 100% meets the challenge.
If executed well, this would provide a backbone for DeFi projects. Timeline is perhaps a little long to hit the fund goal of scaling up DeFi within 6 months

The problem and the solution presented are within the scope of the challenge. The development of financial primitives (bonding curves) has the purpose of providing DeFi dapps (but they can also apply to other niches like NFTs and DAOs for example) with low-level mathematical models, this would allow different applications to leverage on economic models in order to deploy reliable market-focused DApps. This concept would facilitate the development of Dapps, as it would reduce the development time of financial models, allow the use of reliable models, increasing reliability and facilitate composability. The proposal has great potential for impact on Cardano's DeFi ecosystem and this challenge.

The proposal reads like a theoretic research project and not a detailed project plan focused on building an AMM. They're building off an RABC model but the concept is very theoretical and has not been shown to work at scale at all in any Ethereum DeFi protocol.
assessments.reply: Doesn't address the assessment question. Not constructive since the assessment is based on a misreading/framing of the proposal as an AMM product. It is about implementing/engineering a reusable Plutus module for different types of Bonding Curve AMMs. Using the RABC as a motivating use-case that is built upon the module. Treating the referenced economic systems-engineering specifications as theoretical i.e. implying the specifications are not-practical and irrelevent. Several examples of use in Ethereum and Cosmos were provided but have been ignored.

assessments.note: The proposal needs to make their exact plans for the type of AMM/DEX they are working on more clear, other AMM DeFi protocols in this challenge make their plans for implementation very clear, this proposal does not.
assessments.reply: Barely addresses the impact assessment question and is inadequate. A misreading of the proposal as an AMM service/product and not as engineering a reusable Plutus module for AMMs means the feedback is not constructive.

assessments.note: The proposal is overly wordy and includes links to work that no one on the proposing team has been apart of. A protocol as complex as an AMM bonding curve requires a team willing to produce a Whitepaper and technical docs describing their solution in detail. The other AMM protocols in this challenge are more straightforward and present more DeFi compelling solutions with their own content included.
assessments.reply: Does not address the impact assessment question and focuses on a requirement that a proposal must have a whitepaper and technical documentation, which means the CA has not read the proposal. Also the feedback is based on an assumption the proposal is for a single AMM service/product. Completely missing that the proposal is to engineer (and develop the technical documentation for) an open/reusable module of Plutus Bonding curves. Ingores the substantial documented technical research/design (presented as Jupyter notebooks and cadCAD simulation code).

assessments.note: There won't even be a single FTE assigned to this work is a large red flag when most of the other proposals building entire protocols have teams of developers working full time.
assessments.reply: Partially addresses the assessment question but is inadequate and not constructive. The CA has misunderstood the proposal budget. It states in the proposal that the funding is to bootstrap and accelerate the work of up to three team members. In otherwords this it is partially funding the work of a development team, yet the CA says the 0.5 FTE is a redflag because there should be a team of developers.

assessments.note: Team claims the experience to deliver. I do question though given their experience why the timeline is so long. Can you not expedite it, which would also help hit the fund goal.

The team described experiences and qualifications to execute the proposal.

There is a very well articulated and detailed rationale. The plan is reasonable and well structured. There are budget allocation details.

There is a reasonable timeline and the deliverables described therein are within the scope of the challenge brief.

The GitHub link provided is stale and has not been updated with meaningful code commits in half a year. It's also not clear why the proposer is referencing a stale repo that no one on their team contributed work on. A proposal this complex also requires complete technical documentation and again its not clear why the proposer is linking articles on bonding curves from 2019. There is also no Plutus developer resource with a Haskell background identified in the proposal.
assessments.reply: Doesn't really address the assessment question instead focuses on a stale github repo and lack of technical documentation. CA does not appear to understand the proposal. The "stale github repo" is substantial technical research/design documentation (as Jupyter notebooks and simulation code) i.e. a Whitepaper format used by Data Scientists and engineers. Developed by a staff member of IOG on the Plutus team. The implementing team includes experienced software engineers with backgrounds in functional programming and are part of the Plutus Pioneer Programme. The proposal is motivated in-part to help address the fact that there are no experienced Plutus engineers in the wild. Hence the feedback not constructive.

assessments.note: The team behind this proposal includes no original content (WP, technical docs), all of these links included are from other teams and no Haskell Plutus developer resource is identified.
assessments.reply: Feedback not constructive and inadequate. The proposal states it is not attempting to invent a new or novel economic protocol but instead to engineer an existing set of well researched modular protocols. To do that, team includes experienced software engineers with backgrounds in functional programming and are also part of the Plutus Pioneer Programme. The proposal is motivated in-part to help address the fact that there are no experienced Plutus engineers in the wild. Novelity is not a requirement of the challenge, the original challenge proposal lists many protocols that could/should be copied onto Cardano.

assessments.note: The plan presented is not at all clear in its implementation strategy, the Github linked is outdated and it looks like no one on this proposing team worked on it and in addition no Plutus developer building this protocol in Haskell is identified in the proposal plan. There is no technical docs/WP from the proposing team included in this.
assessments.reply: Addresses the assessment question in a constructive way but feedback indicates the CA has not understood the proposal. For instance the work is to develop the code and technical documentation for a reusable model of bonding curves.The team includes experienced software engineers with backgrounds in functional programming (incl. some Haskell) that are also part of the Plutus Pioneer Programme. Comprehensive whitepaper and technical research/design documentation (as Jupyter Notebooks and simulation code) i.e. a Whitepaper format used by Data Scientists, linked to is the basis of the work.

assessments.note: The proposer needs to be more clear in the project statement and proposed solution and include the relevant technical docs needed for DeFi protocol to be completely evaluated.
assessments.reply: Addresses the assessment question but is inadequate. Appears the CA cannot assess the proposals intent or the technical information referenced since the "project statement" to build a reusable bonding curve module is stated multiple times in the proposal.

assessments.note: Proposer of this proposal have not just explained AMM for beginners but have explained how it is gonna execute the proposal and the budget it has asked looks sufficient to take the proposal forward.

Detailed plan. It would be good to have some metrics and goals going forward to meet the fund goal. For instance number (and size) of DeFi projects implementing the modules produced. This would force the proposers to collaborate with potential DeFi projects. To speed up usage will they be providing Beta access to their API's so development have occur in parallel.
assessments.reply: Addressess the assessment question but the CA may not have read the entire proposal since the sugguested metrics are stated in the proposal.

assessments.note:
There is budget breakdown, details about the team. The roadmap describes some milestones as a reference for development over 12 months, this helps in the audit and identification of compliance.

Metrics and deliverables are reasonable and allow audit of the proposal.

This proposal is technically complex, but the problem and the solution have been very well articulated and have been clarified, the alignment with the challenge is evident.

The proposal has provided little to no original content in the proposal, all of the links are 1. from outdated Github repos and articles and 2. are overly theoretical or referencing projects that are not live in production yet.
assessments.reply: Not constructive and appears to be a restatement/copy of CA's prior perspective. The proposal states it is not attempting to invent a new or novel economic protocol but instead to engineer an existing set of modular protocols. The feedback makes a statement about outdated or stale supporting material without demostrating any understanding of the subject matter or manner of material presentation i.e. technical documentation as markdown files, Jupyter notebooks, and simulations). Nor do they provide any newer references to support their outdated statement. A requirement for novelity/originality has not been stated in the challenge, nor is are they a valid assessment for this proposal's stated objective: to focus on implementing well researched and understood protocols.

assessments.note: This proposal reads from my perspective as a research project referencing the work of other teams. Not at all clear how the value prop of this AMM stacks up compared to the other AMM Dex's competing for funding in this challenge. A CA needs more original content to sufficiently audit the progress of this proposal, none of that is possible with the proposal's current state.
assessments.reply: Addresses the assessment question and is constructive but is based on a misunderstanding or misreading of the proposal. It is not a proposal for a DEX but a reusable Plutus module for implemeting DEXes and other protocols/services/DApps. Given the highly technical nature of the space and the proposal such misunderstandings not unreasonable.

assessments.note: This proposal should consider reviewing the other AMM proposals in this challenge as well as the f5 dApp challenge, onboarding the specific Haskell developers needed t build the solution in Plutus, and provide links to their own work, not that of other teams who started work in a different programming language/blockchain.
assessments.reply: Indicates the CA has not read the proposal. For instance the team includes experienced software engineers with backgrounds in functional programming (incl. some Haskell) that are also part of the Plutus Pioneer Programme. The proposal is motivated in-part to help address the fact that there are no experienced Plutus engineers in the wild and this is stated up front. Although we have provided links to prior work done by us, it is not exhaustive in anyway.

solution: A reusable module (money legos) of economic protocols based on bonding curves to scale up continuous project financing and investment.
experience: Financial markets software engineering, cryptocurrency payments, start-ups, data & Govtech, impact investing. Organize legal-tech community.
